block.p: The idea that you can explain the distribution of the "goodies" of life in this country by invoking arguments of race and genes is intellectually dishonest ("Daring Research or 'Social Science Pornography'?" by Jason DeParle, Oct. 9). The public policy implications of "The Bell Curve" are merely Republican prescriptions for laissez-faire policies, with Charles Murray and Richard Herrnstein cloaking their arguments in academic garb to gain respectability. They exalt the virtues of the marketplace and see government policies as assaults on the meritocracy. They ask us to ignore or forget that this meritocracy systematically excluded women, people of color, the disabled, etc. from the competitive process. Their argument is not new. Neither is abuse of so-called scientific research in the service of mean-spirited political objectives. THOMPSON F. WILLIAMS JR. Watertown, Mass.
